Titular: US retailers teeter on the brink as 630,000 outlets close
Subtitular: Analysts predict dozens of nationally-known chains could be headed for insolvency
Texto: Few businesses are in greater need of emergency cash than retailers, yet the $2.2tn US stimulus bill is unlikely to prevent bricks and mortar chains hardest hit by the coronavirus shutdown from going to the wall.While Amazon, Walmart and a handful of other operators have the chance to emerge from the crisis in a stronger position thanks to a boom in online deliveries and the rush for household essentials, much of the rest of the sector is facing a historic crunch.Almost 630,000 outlets in the US have been forced to close due to fears about Covid-19 and restrictions on movement to contain its spread, according to Coresight estimates seen by the Financial Times. With the National Retail Federation calculating that $430bn in industry revenues could evaporate over the next three months, the question is how many of them will reopen.Tens of thousands of retail workers are already being furloughed without pay at Victoria’s Secret owner L Brands, while Macy’s warned its workforce of about 125,000 on Monday that it was unclear when stores could reopen and it would start to furlough most of the staff this week.As companies try to conserve cash, dividend payouts have been postponed at groups, including Nordstrom. At the same time, Best Buy, TJX and Kohl’s are among 126 discretionary consumer companies to draw a total $86bn from credit lines, according to Autonomous Research. Some, such as Mattress Firm, have told landlords that they will fail to make required rent payments for April.Another 30 nationally known US retail companies could file for bankruptcy protection this year, predicted industry consultant Jan Rogers Kniffen. Especially vulnerable are department stores and mall-based clothing chains that have long struggled to stay relevant in the age of Amazon.Retail executives and their advisers are pouring over the details of the congressional rescue bill, which includes $454bn in federal loans available to companies stricken by the crisis.How is coronavirus taking its toll on markets, business, and our everyday lives and workplaces? Stay briefed with our coronavirus newsletter.Sign up hereBig questions remain about how and when businesses can access the funds and the conditions attached, although Matthew Shay, head of the NRF, said that taken as a whole the package promised a “crucial bridge” for the sector. Mickey Chadha, senior credit officer at rating agency Moody’s, added the cash could help investment grade retailers “tide over any temporary liquidity issues”.Long before coronavirus, however, many retailers were battling to keep creditors at bay. Household names including Forever 21 and Pier 1 filed for bankruptcy in recent months and the sector accounted for almost a fifth of US corporate debt that defaulted in the fourth quarter.Junk-rated retailers with large debt burdens, cited by the rating agency Moody’s, include luxury chain Neiman Marcus, with outstanding debt of $6.1bn, mass market department store operator JCPenney ($4.2bn), womenswear company Ascena ($1.8bn) and clothing retailer J Crew ($1.4bn).Mark Cohen, director of retail studies at Columbia University and a former chief executive of Sears Canada, doubted federal loans could resuscitate heavily indebted companies. “A business that was struggling going into this crisis and is already leveraged up is unlikely to recover by taking on additional loans” even on favourable terms, he said.Corporate bond markets have become increasingly concerned about how discretionary retailers will cope. A Macy’s bond that matures in 2023, for instance, has tumbled from above $100 at the start of the month to $70, according to Finra data.Macy’s balance sheet has long been in better shape than more distressed rivals, although the department store chain lost its investment grade rating from S&P Global last month and was cut further into junk territory in a spate of sector downgrades last week.The company, which has already suspended its dividend, drawn on a line of credit and stopped capital spending to shore up its finances, said on Monday that “while these actions have helped, it is not enough”, as it drew up the furlough plans.Not everyone is sure coronavirus will lead directly to a wave of retail bankruptcies. “I expect to see an uptick, as companies that were on the edge have greater risk of falling off the edge quicker, but I don’t believe it will be the Armageddon that everyone thinks,” said Perry Mandarino, head of restructuring and co-head of investment banking at B Riley FBR.Such is the scale of the crisis that the bankruptcy process itself is not functioning properly. New York-based Modell’s Sporting Goods has put liquidation sales on hold as customers are unable to visit its stores, and a judge last week granted its request to suspend Chapter 11 proceedings.One leading restructuring banker argued lenders and landlords would do as much as they could to “hit the pause button” for the duration of the crisis. Prof Cohen added it may well be in creditors’ own interests to be more flexible than usual. “The assets that they would seize are currently worth a fraction of what they were before this erupted,” he said. “There will have to be widespread forbearance.”But creditors have bills of their own to pay — as mall owner Taubman pointed out in a memo to tenants, in which it told them it expected rent obligations to be met.Ultimately the longer business remains at a standstill, said Mr Kniffen, the more retailers will fold. “You can draw down on your revolver, you can furlough your employees, you can refuse to pay rent — but if this goes on for a while, you’re going to run out of levers to pull.”And those companies that come through the shutdown bruised, but intact, face the prospect that the impact will be felt long after the virus has been contained, putting them further behind more dominant rivals.The Financial Times is making key coronavirus coverage free to read to help everyone stay informed. Find the latest here.Restrictions on movement threaten to convert even more consumers both to online shopping — benefiting retailers that have been investing in ecommerce — and to chains that remain open through the crisis such as Walmart, which is taking on 150,000 workers to cope with demand.Amazon — which last week snapped up two store leases from bankrupt New York supermarket Fairway as part of an expanding push into bricks and mortar — is hiring 100,000.John San Marco, research analyst at $356bn asset manager Neuberger Berman, said he was spending much of his time trying to assess how much of the coronavirus disruption would endure. But there was no doubt, he said, that the crisis will lead to “a meaningful acceleration of the retail shake-out”.

Titular: Nordstrom profit beat adds to retail cheer
Subtitular: Luxury chain kept inventory in check and surprised Wall Street despite falling sales
Texto: Nordstrom, the upscale US department store chain, cheered investors with a stronger than expected quarterly profit, despite a 5 per cent decline in sales, adding to fresh optimism over the health of the retail industry.The upbeat results came on the heels of blockbuster earnings from industry heavyweights Target and Lowe’s, whose robust sales growth in the second quarter allayed broader fears of a slowdown in the economy and drove shares across the sector sharply higher.Nordstrom was up nearly 6 per cent during the trading day, and following the publication of its results after the bell the stock jumped as much as 16 per cent more.Net sales fell to $3.78bn from $3.98bn in the second quarter that ended August 3, missing a consensus estimate of $3.93bn.But the Seattle-based company managed to boost profits by keeping inventory in check and reducing expenses. Inventory was down 6.5 per cent compared to the second quarter last year.Nordstrom co-president Erik Nordstrom said Wednesday it was “confident in our ability to manage through cycles” and focused on lifting top-line sales, amid softer results across the retail group’s full-price and discount stores.Shares in Nordstrom settled at around 10 per cent higher in after-hours trading, while the new round of good news added more fuel to some other retailers’. Macy’s was up 1.2 per cent and JCPenney was up 3 per cent after hours, for example.Nordstrom booked $141m in net earnings, or 90 cents a share, down from $162m, or 95 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The company easily eclipsed analysts’ average forecast for earnings per share of 75 cents, according to a Refinitiv poll.Nordstrom attributed its sales decline in the quarter to softer performances for its annual Anniversary Sale in July and its off-price business, noting it experienced a challenging start to the period.In full-price retail, Nordstrom’s net sales declined 6.5 per cent. Off-price sales, which include its Nordstrom Rack stores, were down 1.9 per cent.Nordstrom narrowed its full-year guidance for sales and earnings. Net sales are seen falling approximately 2 per cent, versus a prior view of down 2 per cent to flat. Earnings are expected to come in between $3.25 and $3.50 a share, compared with a range of $3.25 to $3.65. Analysts were looking for fiscal 2019 earnings of $3.27 a share.The company said it is still evaluating the fourth tranche of proposed tariffs from the Trump administration, but added the impact of the potential levies on Chinese goods is expected to be “relatively immaterial for the year”.

Titular: Falling sales at big US department stores spark sell-off
Subtitular: Health of US consumer back in focus after Nordstrom, Kohl’s and JC Penney disappoint
Texto: New signs of trouble at three of the largest department store chains in the US unnerved investors on Tuesday, reigniting questions about the health of bricks-and-mortar retailers and sending share prices tumbling.Falling quarterly sales were reported by Nordstrom, Kohl’s and JC Penney, which between them operate more than 2,300 stores and employ almost 300,000 people. Kohl’s stock closed down 12 per cent and JC Penney 7 per cent. Nordstrom dropped 9 per cent in trading after the bell.The sector has been closely watched by Wall Street since retail sales fell sharply in December. The dramatic drop during such a critical month for consumer spending led some analysts to fret the US economy was beginning to sputter.Since then, data has swung wildly, rebounding with their biggest jump in 18 months in March only to fall sharply again in April. Economists are also concerned the sector could be hit by the White House’s decision to raise tariffs on Chinese goods.Managers at the affected chains insisted the disappointing figures were not due to a sector-wide decline, largely blaming company-specific mis-steps, from marketing problems to floundering loyalty scheme initiatives.After financial markets closed in New York, the upscale Nordstrom chain disclosed a 3.5 per cent decline in net sales from a year ago to $3.4bn. The Seattle-based group warned of a broad-based decline at both its full price and discount businesses, online as well as in stores.There were points in time during the quarter where we just weren’t as competitiveErik Nordstrom, co-president, cited “executional misses”, including a decision to make credits in its loyalty scheme digital-only.The company “later discovered that a segment of our customer base relies on receiving these [rewards] by mail”, he said, and “as a result, we saw a reduction in traffic”. Net earnings dropped from $87m a year ago to $37m.At mass-market retailer JC Penney, relative strength in fine jewellery and clothing failed to offset declines in women’s accessories and handbags, among other goods. Net losses in its fiscal first quarter widened from $78m last time to $154m, while net sales fell 5.6 per cent to $2.4bn.The latest earnings weakness adds to pressure on the Texas-based chain, which carries $3.8bn in long-term debt and whose market capitalisation has collapsed from highs in 2007 of $18.5bn to just $330m.“Re-establishing the fundamentals of our business operations will take time,” said Jill Soltau, chief executive.The department store results were the latest in a batch of mixed earnings reports from consumer-facing companies. US retailers are being squeezed by falling mall traffic, the rise of online shopping and a shift by consumers towards spending more on recreation and travel.Some chains are producing better results, however. Groceries helped Walmart last week report its strongest first-quarter sales in nine years. Macy’s also eked out a sales improvement, saying that recent bad weather had no impact on sales.TJX, which owns Marshalls and TJ Maxx, announced a 5 per cent rise in like-for-like sales on Tuesday. Results from other retailers, including Target and Best Buy, are scheduled for release in coming days.At Kohl’s, some of the chain’s difficulties appeared to be self-inflicted. Michelle Gass, Kohl’s chief executive, said problems in marketing and homewares had contributed to the slower performance.“Some of our key promotional events weren’t as productive,” she acknowledged, while “there were points in time during the quarter where we just weren’t as competitive” in homewares.Kohl’s executives also said that bad weather, in particular unseasonal cold in the Wisconsin-based company’s Midwest and north-east heartlands, had exacerbated the same-store sales decline in its first quarter, down 3.4 per cent from a year ago.Kohl’s also issued a profit warning for the full year. Adjusted earnings were now expected to come in at between $5.15 and $5.45 a share, down from previous guidance of $5.80 to $6.15. Bruce Besanko, chief financial officer, said pressures included higher trade tariffs, which “we just didn’t have baked into our outlook”.Ms Gass added that Kohl’s, which has a partnership with Amazon to allow customers to return items purchased from the ecommerce giant at its stores, added that Kohl’s had “adjustments under way to get us back on track”.

Titular: Nordstrom shares drop after slow holiday sales
Subtitular: Off-price and digital sales jumped, but traffic was soft at department stores
Texto: Nordstrom said slower traffic in its department stores hurt sales during the critical holiday shopping season and warned that full-year earnings will come in around the low end of its guidance.Comparable sales growth of 2.1 per cent year-to-date was in line with its outlook, Nordstrom said, but sales at its full-price department stores fell short of the company’s expectations during the November and December period as shoppers appeared to show a preference for discounts.“As a result, the company has incorporated in its annual expectations higher markdowns taken during holiday and to reposition inventory to a more appropriate level by the end of the year,” the company added in a statement late Tuesday.Shares slipped 6 per cent to $44.43 after falling more than 8 per cent after the opening bell on Wednesday.Nordstrom is one of a few major retailers so far, including Macy’s and Kohl’s, to report disappointing holiday sales despite forecasts for strong consumer spending. MasterCard’s SpendingPulse report tracked more than $850bn in total holiday sales, a 5.1 per cent increase compared to 2017, driven by 19.1 per cent growth in ecommerce.Nordstrom’s comparable sales — a key metric measuring sales at stores open at least 12 months — increased 1.3 per cent year-over-year during the nine weeks ending on January 5. Full-price stores posted just 0.3 per cent growth amid softer traffic. Sales at off-price outlets rose 3.9 per cent.Digital sales, which accounted for 36 per cent of total sales, were up 18 per cent.Nordstrom now expects 2018 earnings near the low end of its prior outlook, which called for a profit of $3.55 to $3.65 a share. Analysts polled by Refinitiv estimated that adjusted earnings would hit $3.58 a share.The company will report full fourth-quarter results on February 28.

Titular: US retail chief Blake Nordstrom dies aged 58
Subtitular: Head of store dynasty was credited with improving group’s merchandising system
Texto: Blake Nordstrom, head of the fourth generation of the eponymous 118-year-old retailing dynasty that reasserted family control over the US company, has died. He was 58.Blake passed away unexpectedly in Seattle on Wednesday. Just three weeks ago the father of two wrote in a note to employees that he had been diagnosed with lymphoma, although at the time he said he would undergo chemotherapy and doctors were encouraged by the prognosis.“My heart goes out to the Nordstrom family and everyone at the company during this difficult time,” said Brad Smith, chairman.Kenneth Cole, the fashion designer, described him as “one of our industry’s truest leaders and finest individuals”.Blake was a great-grandson of John Nordstrom, a Swedish immigrant who made a fortune in the Klondike gold rush and invested it all in a Seattle shoe store. Nordstrom expanded beyond the Pacific Northwest to become one of the country’s largest upmarket retailers, and remained under family leadership until the 1990s.Blake worked at the high-end company over four decades. In spite of his bloodline, and in common with longstanding family policy, he started in the company’s lower ranks.After stints in the stockroom, sales and merchandise, the University of Washington economics graduate worked up through management and eventually became president of its Nordstrom Rack division.He took the helm of the group as president in 2000, aged 39, upon the departure of chairman and chief executive John Whitacre. Whitacre had been the first non-family member to hold the positions, and Blake’s elevation was seen by some on Wall Street as a mini family coup. His father Bruce became chairman and headed the board until 2006.Blake was sole president until 2015, although in practice he ran the chain with his brothers, Pete and Erik, who shared in the decision-making. The retailer has left the chief executive title unoccupied.When Blake took over, Nordstrom had been struggling for several years with weak sales and a declining share price. He cut expenses and reduced inventory as part of a revival plan, and was credited with improving the company’s merchandising system.Nordstrom has sought to deal with the pressures of ecommerce by combining its bricks and mortar presence with technology, trying new store and digital concepts. Initiatives include allowing shoppers to tailor a suit on a screen before trying it in the dressing room.Blake also sought to restore the company’s reputation for customer service, permitting consumers to collect items from stores in the early hours of the morning and return items without being quizzed by staff.Nordstrom has not escaped the difficulties in US retail, although it has coped better than rivals that have resorted to big store closures. The company generated $15.1bn in net sales in its 2017 fiscal year. Its market capitalisation stands at $7.99bn.The chain bucked the industry-wide trend for closures by opening its first all-line Manhattan store last year. It plans to follow the men’s store opening with a women’s outlet across the street this year.The business remains under family management, with Pete and Erik at the helm as co-presidents. Family members still own about 30 per cent of the stock.Blake was part of a group that had hoped to take the company private last year, but a special committee for the board rejected the price as inadequate.

Titular: Nordstrom full-price sales cool as customers opt for discount aisle
Texto: Nordstrom on Thursday said full-price sales at the upscale department store cooled in the third quarter as consumers shopped in its bargain aisles, helping the company to better-than-expected revenues but a drop in its gross margin.The Seattle-based company said like-for-like sales rose 2.3 per cent in the third quarter in line with forecasts. However, shoppers eschewed full-price merchandise, instead lapping up discounted items.Comparable sales at its full-price stores rose just 0.4 per cent, down from 4.1 per cent in the second quarter. By comparison, its discount or so-called off-price channels recorded a 5.8 per cent increase in comparable sales, up from 4 per cent the previous quarter.Revenues rose 3.3 per cent from a year ago to $3.75bn, ahead of analysts’ estimate for $3.69bn, according to a survey of analysts by Refinitiv.Nordstrom, like other retailers and department stores, has faced a decline in mall traffic amid rising competition from e-commerce competitors like Amazon and off-price rivals like TJX Cos that offer steep discounts.In order to fend off competition Nordstrom, like others in its industry, has expanded its own discount offerings through its Nordstrom Rack brand and invested in its online operations and loyalty program.However, strength in the US economy and upbeat consumer sentiment has helped fuel sales at retailers, with some like Macy’s and Walmart posting solid sales gains.The company, which earlier this year failed in a bid to take the business private, said its third-quarter net income fell to $67m, or 39 cents a share, down from $114m, or 67 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. The company said it incurred a $72m charge associated with delinquent Nordstrom credit card accounts that were charged higher interest in error.Gross profit as a percentage of net sales slipped 137 basis points to 33.3 per cent.Looking ahead, the company took a slightly rosier view and now expects full-year net sales of between $15.5bn to $15.6bn, up from its previous outlook for $15.4bn to $15.5bn. Nordstrom also nudged higher the lower end of its earnings outlook and now predicts full-year earnings of between $3.55 to $3.65 a share, up from $3.50 to $3.65 a share.Nordstrom shares tumbled 11 per cent in after-hours trade, having ended the day 3.5 per cent lower. The department store chain’s shares are up nearly 25 per cent year-to-date.

Titular: Nordstrom on track for best day in four years
Texto: Nordstrom is roaring towards its biggest one-day gain in more than four years on Friday, after the upscale US department-store chain’s latest quarterly earnings report put it back in fashion on Wall Street.Shares of the Seattle-based company were up 11.55 per cent in midday trading to $58.32, putting them on course for their largest one-day percentage gain since May 2014, according to Thomson Reuters data.The sharp rise comes a day after Nordstrom reported stronger-than-expected earnings. Comparable sales, a key industry metric measuring sales growth, were up 4 per cent year-on-year in the quarter, sailing past expectations for a smaller 0.8 per cent advance, which the company credited to solid growth at both its full-price namesake department stores and its off-price Nordstrom Rack chain.Wall Street was particularly keen on the advances Nordstrom made in expanding digital sales, seen as a key buffer against the pressures exerted on the traditional brick-and-mortar sector by e-commerce giants like Amazon. Digital sales grew 23 per cent year-on-year to comprise 34 per cent of second-quarter sales, up from 29 per cent last year.Its popular anniversary sales attracted “record digital demand”, the company said, hurdling over its previous peak by 80 per cent. On the strength of the current quarter, Nordstrom boosted its earnings and revenue outlook for the full year.The enthusiastic embrace for Nordstrom contrasts with the much cooler reception for rival Macy’s, which dropped nearly 16 per cent earlier this week despite generally solid results.Friday’s gain has taken Nordstrom’s year-to-date gain to 23 per cent, after barely moving in 2017.

Titular: Nordstrom shares shoot higher on strong sales growth
Texto: Nordstrom shares soared on Thursday after the upscale US department-store chain raised its full-year revenue and earnings outlook following stronger-than-expected quarterly sales growth.Nordstrom shares were up 12.8 per cent in after-hours trading, signalling Wall Street’s enthusiasm for its latest quarterly earnings.During the quarter ended August 4, net sales rose 7.1 per cent year-on-year to $3.98bn, while net earnings came in at $162m, versus $110m a year ago. Earnings per diluted share were 95 cents improved on the 65 cents posted in the year-ago period.Analysts had been looking for net sales of $3.95bn and net earnings of $143.57m, or 84 cents a share, per Thomson Reuters.Comparable sales — a key industry metric for sales growth — were up 4 per cent year-on -year in the quarter, sailing well past expectations for a 0.8 per cent advance.The company credited the results to solid performance at both its full-price Nordstrom stores — thanks to strong contributions from kids apparel and beauty categories — and its off-price Nordstrom Rack line. Its digital offerings also continued to gain ground, as it fends off competition from online retailers, with digital sales up 23 per cent from a year ago, representing 34 per cent of overall quarterly sales, a bigger slice than the 29 per cent racked up last year.Crediting its first-half performance, Nordstrom raised its full-year earnings per share outlook. It is now setting its sights on a range of $3.50 to $3.65, up from its previous forecast for $3.35 to $3.55. It also nudged higher its net sales outlook, forecasting a range of $15.4bn to $15.5bn, up from $15.2bn to $15.4bn previously.Nordstrom, like other retailers traditionally reliant on brick-and-mortar stores, has been retrenching in recent years in response to shifting shopping habits. Strong consumer spending during 2018, however, has helped to lift earnings for a broad range of retailers, including Walmart, although rival department-store chain Macy’s latest quarterly report left Wall Street underwhelmed despite generally solid numbers.Earlier this year, its board pulled the plug on discussions with members of its founding family about a potential takeover deal, saying they had not been able to reach an agreement on the right price.After ending 2017 relatively flat, Nordstrom shares are up more than 10 per cent so far this year.

Titular: Nordstrom falls out of fashion as forecasts underwhelm
Texto: Nordstrom shares were relegated to the discount bin on Tuesday after the US department store operator reaffirmed its prior outlook, disappointing those on Wall Street who had been hoping for an upgrade.The stock was down nearly 4.6 per cent in lunchtime trade, putting it on track for its worst one day slide in nearly two months and making it the biggest laggard in the S&P 500.The drop comes as the upmarket retailer reiterated its sales and earnings guidance for the current fiscal year. In a trading update ahead of its investor day, the company said it expects sales to come in at $15.2bn-$15.4bn, compared to the $15.7bn that analysts are forecasting.Same-store sales are predicted to grow between 0.5 and 1.5 per cent while earnings per share is expected to come in the $3.35 to $3.55 range. The market is looking for a 0.8 per cent rise in same-store sales and EPS of $3.46.The update comes as Nordstrom looks to convince investors of its growth prospects after a failed attempt by the Nordstrom family to take the company private earlier this year.Like other US retailers, Nordstrom is facing unprecedented upheaval amid falling mall traffic, shifting shopping patterns that prioritise recreation spending, and fierce competition from online and off-price retailers that offer branded goods at steep discounts.The company, the largest US high-end department chain with 373 stores across 40 states, has sought to adapt with the expansion of its own discount chain Nordstrom Rack, which sells branded clothing at reduced prices. The chain has been a bright spot, helping to attract bargain hunters and driving a 0.8 per cent rise in same-store sales at the company last year.Nordstrom plans to outline its strategy to become “the best fashion retailer in a digital world” at its investor day on Tuesday. It said in its trading update that it is aiming for sales to grow by an average of 3-4 per cent every year until 2022.

Titular: Emerging market debt burdens may be sorely understated
Subtitular: Recent paper suggests overseas liabilities of EMs are greater than previously thought
Texto: For emerging economies, coronavirus struck first through the financial markets. Long before the numbers of cases and deaths in these countries began to spread alarm, many emerging markets experienced a sudden halt in foreign investment inflows.Overseas investors have taken $95bn out of EM stocks and bonds since late January, according to the Institute of International Finance, dwarfing the withdrawals that followed the onset of the global financial crisis in September 2008.As Covid-19 infections rise and fragile health systems struggle to cope, foreign investors may be low on the list of concerns for EM governments. But these outflows will have a big impact on the fiscal measures policymakers can bring to bear on the crisis.Emerging markets’ overseas liabilities, moreover, may be bigger than previously imagined. A paper published by Matteo Maggiori at Stanford and colleagues at Harvard, Chicago Booth and Columbia Business School suggests the true ownership of EM bonds by overseas investors is much greater than shown in standard data — in some countries, by many multiples.The paper also suggests that foreign holdings of shares issued by Chinese companies may be many times greater than the $160bn that shows up in US national accounts. Should US-China relations sour in the aftermath of the coronavirus crisis, these giant holdings could become a source of significant risk.Mr Maggiori and his colleagues question the normal practice of allocating securities in national accounts on the basis of the residency rather than the nationality of their issuer. It may make sense, for example, for a bond issued by a Brazilian subsidiary of Banco Santander to be added to the debt statistics of Brazil (the residency of its issuer) rather than Spain (the nationality of the issuer’s ultimate owner), because the bond’s proceeds are likely to be put to use in Brazil.But it makes much less sense for a bond issued by Petrobras International Finance Company, a Cayman Island subsidiary of the Brazilian oil group, to be added to the debt statistics of the Cayman Islands. Yet that is what happens in standard, residency-based financial statistics such as the US’s Treasury International Capital data (TIC) and the IMF’s Coordinated Portfolio Investment Survey (CPIS).Mr Maggiori says this results in a vast understatement of the investments by US, European and other international investors in emerging economies. So the academics developed an algorithm to reallocate the securities logged in the TIC and CPIS data according to nationality rather than residency.The results are startling. TIC data show that US ownership of Brazilian bonds at the end of 2017 amounted to $8bn, based on the residency of issuers. But restated by nationality, the total rises to $68bn. For Chinese bonds, the total rises from $3bn to $55bn. Mr Maggiori says the results sound a warning as the coronavirus crisis threatens to tip emerging markets into a debt crisis.“If we are going to see a wave of corporate defaults, it’s a risk worth thinking about that a lot of issuance has taken place offshore,” he said. “[Our work] shows that exposures are quite large.”What is also striking is the role played by tax havens such as the Cayman Islands. In the TIC data, of Brazil’s $59bn in reallocated bonds, $42bn were issued in tax havens. Of China’s $52bn, $44bn were issued in tax havens. The results also shine a light on the role of so-called variable interest equity structures in US investments in Chinese companies. VIEs allow US investors to hold shares in these companies, circumventing Chinese restrictions on foreign ownership of some operating businesses. But in these transactions what investors actually buy are shares in listed companies, generally resident in the Cayman Islands, that give them a claim on the profits of Chinese operating businesses.By reallocating such investments on the basis of nationality rather than residence, the paper shows that US “ownership” of Chinese companies at the end of 2017 was not $160bn, as shown in US national statistics, but $700bn. This puts it closer to the amount of Chinese ownership of US Treasuries, of about $1.1tn. This is significant because Chinese regulators are certainly aware of the smoke-and-mirrors act being carried out by VIEs. They could, should they wish, bring the practice to an end.Mr Maggiori is not suggesting they will. But he thinks the risk is worth noting. “You read a lot about the possibility of China dumping its US Treasuries but very little about the possibility of China imposing its own regulations. If we’re talking about one, we should certainly be talking about the other,” he said.jonathan.wheatley@ft.com

Titular: Nordstrom sales growth disappoints despite decent earnings
Texto: Solid revenue and profit growth was not enough to save department store Nordstrom from getting marked down after its sales growth fell short of analysts’ target.Shares of the upscale US department store chain dropped 6 per cent in after-hours trading on Thursday following its quarterly report for the three months to May 5.During that time, net sales grew 5.8 per cent from a year ago to $3.47bn, thanks in part to a boost from an event for members of its Nordstrom Rewards programme.Net earnings rose to $87m, or 51 cents per diluted share, from $63m a year ago, or 37 cents. Its gross profit dropped 21 basis points from a year earlier to 34.1 per cent of net sales, which Nordstrom credited to higher occupancy expenses related to openings of its off-price Rack stores in the US and Canada, as well as pre-launch expenses for its Nordstrom Men’s store in New York City.Analysts had been looking for sales of $3.45bn and net income of $72m, or 43 cents a share, according to Thomson Reuters data.While the headline numbers came in ahead of Wall Street forecasts, comparable sales — a key industry metric measuring sales growth — came in at just 0.6 per cent for the overall company. For its full-price stores and websites, comparable sales were up 0.7 per cent, while its off-price lines, including Nordstrom Rack, registered just an 0.4 per cent increase.The comparable sales trends are a reversal from a year ago, when the metric for the entire company and full-price stores was in decline, while the off-price line rang up 2.3 per cent growth.Nordstrom, like other department stores, is facing a fierce competition as more shoppers flock online rather than to brick-and-mortar stores. Its off-price lines, however, had been a recent bright spot, as it helped attract bargain hunters.Two of its department store rivals — Macy’s and Dillard’s — had set the bar high by reporting better than expected results earlier this week.Nordstrom’s founding family recently explored a potential takeover deal, but the company’s board announced in March that it had ended discussions since they had been unable to reach an agreement on the right price.After falling 1.15 per cent last year, Nordstrom shares are up about 7.5 per cent so far in 2018.

Titular: Macy’s leads decline on downgrade as department stores slip
Texto: Department store shares were dropped in the sales basket on Thursday after analysts at Morgan Stanley downgraded Macy’s and said they are cautious on the department store sector, souring sentiment ahead of their results next week.Shares in Macy’s fell nearly 3 per cent to $29.29, while Nordstrom shares fell 1.7 per cent to $48.42. Kohl’s shares declined 1.6 per cent to $60.39, and JC Penney shares were off by about 1.9 per cent to $2.83.The bear camp on Macy’s swelled after analysts at Morgan Stanley cut the stock to “underweight” from “equal weight” and lowered the price target to $25, from $27, citing the company’s “ongoing negative store comps and continued decline in return on invested capital (ROIC)”. That left Macy’s with 5 “buy” ratings, 11 “hold” ratings and 3 “sell” ratings on Wall Street.Kimberly Greenberger, analyst at Morgan Stanley, said Macy’s ROIC declined sharply from 2014 through the third quarter of last year. However, Macy’s shares have jumped 61 per cent since then, on the back of its real estate sales and the US tax reform.“However, we expect ROIC to deteriorate in 2018 after 1Q and thus expect the stock price to decline once again,” Ms Greenberger, said. “Furthermore, Macy’s increased reliance on private label credit card income and real estate gains masks the underlying deterioration in core retail EBIT.”More broadly, Ms Greenberger blamed “secular headwinds such as ecommerce disintermediation, market share loss, ecommerce EBIT margin pressure, and apparel price deflation” as reasons for remaining cautious on the broader department store sector.US department stores have struggled amid falling mall traffic and rising competition from e-commerce retailers. The companies that overbuilt during the boom times have been shuttering stores and investing in their online operations as they work to lure consumers back.Macy’s unofficially kicks off earnings season for department stores when it delivers its quarterly update on Wednesday.

Titular: Nordstrom: not like Mike
Subtitular: Management buyouts require telling one story to shareholders, another to backers
Texto: See what thou hath wrought, Michael Dell? The computing pioneer inspired would-be buyout teams by engineering a complex $25bn purchase of his eponymous tech company five years ago. He rationalised that the software and PC markets were going through so much change that he could only restructure Dell outside the public market.The family behind the luxury department store chain Nordstrom has recently spent months trying to pull off the same trick. The board terminated discussions on Tuesday with the family over disagreements on an acceptable buyout price, unable to find the point where shareholders are persuaded to throw in the towel but where private equity and banks can buy their vision.*Nordstrom might at least have partial protection from the carnage in American retail. A quarter of its sales are already online. Its stores are in better shopping malls. Even so, its share price last autumn, before the family’s public interest in a deal, was half that of its level as recently as 2015.The family’s recent bid for the company at $50 per share, a modest 24 per cent premium, implied an enterprise vale of roughly $10bn. It had arranged for up to $2bn of private equity and $7.5bn of debt. Big buyouts, however, can hinge on the amount of equity the family contributes. The Nordstroms were willing to put up 80 per cent of their $2.5bn stake, cashing out only $500m. After that $50 a share offer was rejected, the family bowed out on Tuesday. Whatever special insight they had into the business was not enough to convince funders to go higher. At the same time, shareholders liked Nordstrom’s prospects enough to reject a premium bid.The consensus is that Mr Dell, buying at a cyclical trough, got the best of minority shareholders. By selling some shares and keeping the rest, the Nordstrom family wanted the best of both worlds. Shareholders noticed and were appropriately unappreciative.* This has been amended from the original article to reflect that it was the board that terminated deal discussions.

Titular: Nordstrom says takeover talks with founding family are over
Texto: Nordstrom’s board is ending discussions with members of its founding family about a potential takeover deal, saying that they had not been able to reach an agreement on the right price for the upscale US department store chain.Nordstrom shares fell nearly 5 per cent in after-hours trading following the announcement, which comes just weeks after the company said that an offer from a group comprising members of the Nordstrom family — including co-presidents Blake, Peter and Erik Nordstrom and chairman emeritus Bruce Nordstrom — had undervalued it.A special committee formed by the board to evaluate the offer said in a statement on Tuesday evening:The Special Committee believes that Nordstrom is well positioned to capitalise on future opportunities to gain market share through its customer strategy, centred on three strategic pillars: providing a differentiated product offering; delivering exceptional services and experiences; and leveraging the strength of its brand. Nordstrom continues to integrate its digital and physical assets to deliver best-in-class capabilities across supply chain, technology, marketing, product and services to better serve customers on their terms.The company is uniquely positioned in the industry and has generated market share gains and industry leading e-commerce penetration fuelled by investments in digital capabilities to expand customer reach and engagement. The Special Committee is confident that the company’s ability to leverage its digital capabilities and its local market assets of people, product, and place will support growth across both its full-price and off-price businesses.The family group had previously offered $50 a share for the shares it did not already own, valuing the retailer at just under $10bn when including its net debt.Like other US department stores, Nordstrom has been working to adapt to an era in which shoppers increasingly choose ecommerce over brick-and-mortar stores. It has been working to enhance its digital offerings and made steady gains in the burgeoning off-price retail sector with its Nordstrom Rack stores.

Titular: Nordstrom rejects founding family’s takeover offer
Texto: US department store Nordstrom rejected a takeover offer from its founding family on Monday, saying a bid by the group undervalued the retailer of Burberry trenchcoats and Balenciaga leather tote bags.A group including the Nordstrom family — including Blake, Peter, Erik and James — offered the storied retailer $50 a share for the shares it did not already own, valuing the company at just under $10bn when including its net debt. Shares in Nordstrom fell nearly 3 per cent in after-hours trading to $50.52.“The special committee has reviewed the group’s indicative acquisition proposal, in consultation with its financial adviser and legal counsel, and has determined that the price proposed is inadequate,” the company said in a statement.

Titular: Nordstrom holiday sales grow as it explores take-private deal
Texto: Nordstrom reported better than expected sales during the critical holiday shopping season, even as its founding family discusses a possible transaction to take the US luxury department-store chain private.The company said on Thursday that sales for the quarter ending February 3 were up 8.4 per cent from a year ago to $4.6bn, in line with analysts’ estimates. Net earnings of $151m were down from the $201m racked up during the year-ago period, thanks in part to a $42m charge related to US tax reform.Earnings per diluted share of 89 cents, reflecting a 25 cent charge related to the tax provision, were less than the $1.24 that analysts had expected.Comparable sales, a key industry metric, rose 2.6 per cent during the quarter, which encompassed the holiday shopping season. That trumped analysts’ expectations for an advance of just 1 per cent. That reflect a 2.4 per cent gain for comparable sales among its full-line Nordstrom stores, as well as Nordstrom.com, and a 3.7 per cent increase for its off-price Nordstrom Rack brand, reflecting the increasing popularity of these discount-focused stores.The company said it expect net sales of $15.2bn-$15.4bn in fiscal year 2018, just a hair over the $15.1bn in net sales recorded for FY 2017 and comparable sales growth of 0.5 to 1.5 per cent.Nordstrom shares, which fell just over 1 per cent in 2017, are up about 6 per cent so far this year.The founding Nordstrom family has been pursuing talks about a possible transaction to take the company private once more, as it tries to position itself to compete in a fast-evolving retail landscape. The company said on Thursday that it does not plan to make any further share repurchases while the talks are ongoing. About $414m in authorisations remain.Its shares were down more than 4 per cent in after-hours trading.

Titular: Holiday sales growth helps brighten Nordstrom’s profit forecast
Texto: US luxury department-store chain Nordstrom is marking up the bottom end of its full-year profit forecast range after an upswing in sales during the all-important holiday shopping season.The company said on Tuesday afternoon that net sales rose 2.5 per cent in the nine weeks ending December 30, compared to the same period a year earlier. Comparable sales, a key industry metric, grew 1.2 per cent year-over-year.The biggest boost came from Nordstrom Rack, the company’s off-price brand, and its “Haute Look” members-only bargain site, which together saw net sales advance 8.2 per cent, and comparable sales increase 2.9 per cent.By contrast, sales from full-line Nordstrom stores — including Nordstrom.com — were up 0.7 per cent, with comparable sales advancing 1 per cent.Following the holiday results, Nordstrom said it is now looking for net sales to grow 4.2 per cent this year, including an 0.5 per cent increase in comparable sales. It has boosted thebottom line of its earnings-per-share forecast from a range of $2.85-$2.95 to $2.90-$2.95.“This reflects sales performance near the high end of the Company’s outlook range, continued stability in merchandise margins and expected deleverage from higher supply chain, technology, and occupancy expenses associated with Nordstrom’s growth initiatives,” the company said in a release.Nordstrom’s full-year and fourth-quarter financial results are due out March 1.Shares of the company had taken a hit last October after the company shelved plans to take itself private in 2017. It had said that it would restart the process after the holiday shopping season was over.Nordstrom shares were down 1.34 per cent in after-hours trading.

Titular: Investors bet against happy holidays for retailers
Subtitular: Macy’s, Nordstrom and Kohl’s are among the most heavily shorted retail stocks in the US
Texto: Investors have sharply increased their bets against the US retail sector ahead of the holiday shopping season, anticipating that shoppers will continue their migration to the internet from the local mall.So-called short interest in US retail stocks — the proportion of a company’s shares on loan to short sellers who are betting they will fall in value — has reached the highest level in at least two years, after jumping 17 per cent in the past month, according to IHS Markit.The holiday shopping season kicks off in earnest in the US this week, with the traditional “Black Friday” sales that draw shoppers after the Thanksgiving Day holiday.Macy’s, the department store chain, is among the most shorted retailers with short interest topping 17 per cent of the underlying shares, an increase of more than 40 per cent over the past month. Short interest for rival Nordstrom was 12 per cent, Kohl’s 11 per cent while Target topped 6 per cent.Across all of the S&P 500’s retail constituents, 5.6 per cent of shares outstanding were on loan to short sellers at the end of last week. By contrast, short interest for the benchmark S&P 500 index was 2.7 per cent.“This is one of the easier trades you put on around the holidays,” says Nicholas Colas, co-founder of DataTrek, an investment newsletter. “You short retail before the holidays because invariably the reality never lives up to the hype.”He added that this year “it does seem like investors and traders are shorting retail because they feel Amazon and other online retailers will have a great year and take more share away from brick and mortar retail”.Short interest in Amazon amounted to just 0.14 per cent of its float.While analysts are forecasting record Black Friday sales, the holiday season caps off a torrid year for retailers.Department stores, the anchors of American shopping malls, have been particularly brutalised by the shift towards ecommerce. Macy’s this month reported same-store sales shrunk for the 11th straight quarter. Nordstrom last month abandoned plans to go private after financing dried up. Kohl’s in the third quarter squeezed out its first sales rise in nearly two years: of 0.1 per cent.“No one has yet proven that they can withstand the Amazon onslaught, particularly over Black Friday,” says Joel Bines, director at AlixPartners, a consultancy. Some retailers are slashing prices to try to maintain market share as fewer people walk into malls to shop, but this strategy eats into margins.Still, short selling can be a risky strategy for investors, as even modestly positive surprises in performance can prompt a big share price jump. In a “short squeeze”, short sellers are forced to buy stock to cover their positions, accelerating the upward move and exacerbating their losses.Last Friday, for example, Abercrombie & Fitch and Foot Locker jumped more than 20 per cent in a matter of minutes.”Retailers have done a very good job of lowering expectations dramatically,” says Mr Bines. “Even the slightest beat can result in a giant increase in market value on a percentage basis.”

Titular: Winners and losers emerge in US department store war
Subtitular: Retailers reveal diverging fortunes as they clear inventory for holiday season
Texto: A flurry of earnings results revealed diverging fortunes of US department stores as they tried to clear inventory ahead of the critical holiday shopping season.In the three months to October, which includes the back-to-school season, Macy’s lost 4 per cent of comparable sales, marking nearly three years of quarterly declines, while Nordstrom reported comparable sales fell 0.9 per cent, a steeper drop than Wall Street had expected.But striking a brighter note was Kohl’s, which squeezed out its first sales rise in nearly two years, and JC Penney, which reported sales double that of consensus forecasts. It has been a punishing year for US department stores, with investors broadly selling the stocks of the stores that typically anchor malls, as more people shop online. The department store sub-index of the S&P 500 has fallen by nearly a third this year, while Credit Suisse estimates more than 140m sq ft of retail will be shut this year. The tough trading environment forced JC Penney to issue a surprise profit warning last month, while Nordstrom suspended its efforts to go private after financing dried up in the wake of Toys R Us’ unexpected bankruptcy.Investors appeared poised to pick winners from losers based on the latest income statements, however. Macy’s stock was up 2.9 per cent in afternoon trade on Friday, despite its sales loss, as the company also maintained its guidance for the year. JCPenney surged more than 14 per cent. Kohl’s stock was 3.7 per cent higher, while shares in Nordstrom slid 1.7 per cent.JC Penney chief Marvin Ellison said the better sales proved its aggressive discounting was “the right decision” even as it hit profits in the quarter. The company has been slashing prices to get rid of leftover clothes, particularly in its women’s section, “allowing for an improved apparel assortment heading into the holiday season”, he said. Moody’s commended Kohl’s and Macy’s for controlling inventory tightly, a strategy that comes “in stark contrast” to JC Penney’s liquidation sales. The idea is to restrict inventory to avoid resorting to steep discounts for unsold items left on the rack, to “adapt to the changing competitive environment”, said Christina Boni, Moody’s vice-president.JC Penney has endured the steepest losses of the group this year, losing two-thirds of its value as it shut stores and revised down guidance. However, big sales helped increase like-for-like sales by 1.7 per cent, lifting its stock even as it revealed a loss of 41 cents a share in the quarter. The results were muddied by the impact from the severe hurricanes that ravaged Puerto Rico, Texas and Florida, with all four of the department store chains claiming the storms had hurt sales in the quarter. Nordstrom and Macy’s said the hurricanes wiped $20m from sales, while Kohl’s estimated a $15m hit. The chief executives of Macy’s and Kohl’s also blamed soft sales on unusually warm weather, curbing shoppers’ appetites for winter jackets and boots.

Titular: Nordstrom shares slip as key sales figure falls more than expected
Texto: Nordstrom shares fell in extended trading after the department store chain said on Thursday that comparable sales fell more than expected in the third quarter, even as earnings topped analysts’ estimates.Shares in the Seattle-based chain fell 4 per cent after hours to $38.50 after it said comparable sales — a measure of sales in stores open at least 12 months — fell 0.9 per cent, steeper than expectations for a 0.3 per cent slide, according to data provider FactSet.The department-store chain — which scrapped plans to take itself private this year following reports that banks were wary of providing financing for the deal — said net sales rose 2 per cent to $3.5bn compared to analysts’ expectations of $3.58bn. Total revenues climbed 2.5 per cent to $3.6bn.The company swung to a profit of $114m, or 67 cents a share, compared with a loss of $10m, or 6 cents a share, in the year-ago period. That eclipsed analysts’ estimates for earnings of 64 cents.Nordstrom said a string of hurricanes that battered Puerto Rico, Florida and Texas shaved about 4 cents off its earnings. Its previous year’s figures were impacted by a goodwill impairment charge of $197m.At 34.7 per cent, tetail gross profit, as a percentage of net sales, decreased 12 basis points compared with the year-ago period.Nordstrom’s results follow mixed quarterly updates from Macy’s and Kohl’s earlier on Thursday. Department stores are struggling to revive sales at a time when rising online competition, a fall in mall traffic, and consumers’ preference for spending on “experiences” rather than things are dampening their business. Moreover, department stores, which bulked up during boom times, are also working to right-size their store fleet and inventory and to cut costs.Looking ahead, the company continues to expect net sales to rise about 4 per cent and for comparable sales to remain flat. However, it did lower the high-end of its earnings outlook to a range of between $2.85 to $2.95 a share, from $2.85 to $3.00 a share previously.Nordstrom shares are down nearly 17 per cent so far this year.

Titular: Nordstrom slides after move to go private is put on hold
Subtitular: Family behind US department store group postpones deal until next year
Texto: US department store chain Nordstrom has scrapped plans to take itself private this year, just weeks after reports that banks were wary of providing financing for the deal.The 116-year-old chain on Monday said it plans to restart the process of going private after the all-important holiday shopping season. It added that a special committee formed to oversee a sale was “prepared to thoroughly evaluate such a proposal from the group at that time, if one is made”. The company, co-founded by Swedish immigrant John W Nordstrom with money made in the Alaskan gold rush, stunned Wall Street in June when it said members of the Nordstrom family were considering a buyout as they look to navigate the industry-wide slowdown in sales. Family members own roughly 30 per cent of the group.Shares had initially jumped on expectations that Nordstrom was going private after nearly 40 years as a public company. However, those gains receded in recent weeks following reports that the family was struggling to secure the financing needed for the deal. The abrupt bankruptcy of Toys R Us, following others including Payless Shoes and Gymboree in recent months, also put lenders on edge. On Monday Nordstrom shares fell more than 6 per cent, pushing them to sit 15 per cent lower this year, on the news the family had put the brakes on a deal. Highlights of the FT’s coverage of how online shopping is disrupting the US retail sectorFounded in 1901 as a single shoe shop in Seattle, Nordstrom grew into a traditional anchor in American shopping malls. The company has fared better than peers, but has still been bruised as changing shopping habits and a glut of mall space has ravaged traditional US retailers in the past year. The largest US high-end department chain, with 360 stores that span 40 states and Canada, has sought to adapt with the expansion of its own discount chain Nordstrom Rack, which sells branded clothing at reduced prices. Nordstrom last month unveiled plans to open its first store without inventory, serving instead as a hub for customers to talk to a stylist or pick up their online purchases. According to the New York Post, the Nordstrom family has been in talks with private equity group Leonard Green, which was reportedly interested in providing $1bn to fund the deal. However, the firm’s participation was contingent on bank financing being arranged, given that a buyout could cost as much as $10bn. Any buyout deal would require the family to acquire the rest of Nordstrom’s outstanding shares. Nordstrom on Monday said it would “remain focused on running the business”.

Titular: Nordstrom shares drop on report of faltering take-private talks
Texto: Nordstrom shares were back in the sales bin on Monday following a report that a deal to take the upmarket department store operator private could be falling apart.The stock fell more than 7 per cent, making it the biggest loser on the S&P 500, after the New York Post reported on Sunday that the take-private talks between members of the Nordstrom family and private equity firm Leonard Green are “faltering”.The report said the Nordstrom family was struggling to secure the financing needed for the deal, with banks reluctant to lend following Toys ‘R’ Us’s abrupt bankruptcy filing last month.The Seattle-based retailer stunned Wall Street in early June when it said members of the Nordstrom family were considering a buyout of the company in order to better weather the industry-wide slowdown in sales.The family has been in talks with Leonard Green, which was reportedly interested in supplying $1bn to fund the deal. According to the NY Post, the PE firm’s participation was contingent on bank financing getting arranged given that a buyout could cost as much as $10bn.Shares in Nordstrom, which had advanced by as much 24 per cent since June, were trading 7.2 per cent lower at $43,75, giving it a market value of $7.28bn.Any buyout deal would require the family to acquire 100 per cent of Nordstrom’s outstanding shares.

Titular: Traditional retailers outperform Amazon this month
Subtitular: Turnround after tough year for sector as S&P 500 moves to fresh high
Texto: Shares of retailers are on track for the best month in more than a year as investors return to a sector that has been cast into the bargain bin on fears that traditional bricks-and-mortar stores are destined to disappear.Experts have long been warning that online shopping would ultimately replace physical stores but concern over this trend accelerated this year with the stock of ecommerce behemoth Amazon surpassing $1,000 while shares tied to traditional retailers sold off.In September so far, however, the retailing sector of the S&P 500 has climbed 4 per cent — the best month since July 2016.“The greatest percentage of earnings per share beats and upward revisions in years triggered positive headlines and upgrades of several left-for-dead retail stocks,” analysts at Nomura Instinet wrote in a report this month, adding that “yet, despite the positives, [the second quarter] saw the worst EPS growth in years”.Shares of Macy’s are up 9.1 per cent so far this month, having lost 42 per cent from the start of the year through to the end of August.Amazon, which is also in the index, was lagging with a gain of 1.9 per cent in September, but it rose by about a third in the first eight months of this year.At the close in New York, Nordstrom had rallied 6 per cent to $47.74 on a report that its founding family was nearing a deal with Leonard Green, the private equity firm, to take the company private.Shares in the department store were down about 7 per cent from the start of the year through to the end of August.The broader US equity market was marginally higher on the day, with the S&P 500 ending at a record high.The S&P 500 rose 0.1 per cent to 2,498.37 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2 per cent to 22,158.18, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite ticked up 0.1 per cent to 6,460.19.The gains by retailing shares has accompanied a drop in the cost to insure against their defaults, despite the issues that the industry still confronts.The cost to protect against a default by Macy’s slid to its lowest level since March on Wednesday, according to Bloomberg data. The cost to buy credit default swaps that insures investors in case of a default by Kohl’s hit its lowest level of the year while Gap CDS costs fell to near two-year lows.In spite of the price moves in September, the overall outlook for traditional retail remains bleak. Fitch Ratings on Wednesday warned about the potential fallout for credit in the event of a US retail “shock scenario”.“A hypothetical rapid rise in Amazon’s US apparel market share could have significant credit implications for existing retailers, [real estate investment trusts] and [commercial mortgage-backed securities] transactions,” the rating agency said.“Sharp declines in retailer revenue and margins and accelerated store closings would likely drive significant cash flow erosion and weaken credit profiles for apparel-focused retailers, mall Reits and retail-heavy CMBS deals in such a scenario.”Additional reporting by Eric Platt in New York

Titular: Nordstrom shares jump on reports it’s nearing take-private deal
Texto: Nordstrom shares jumped in after-hours trading on Tuesday after a report that its founding family was nearing a deal with a private-equity firm that would allow them to take the the publicly traded department-store chain private.The company’s shares were up almost 9 per cent after the bell. CNBC had reported that the founding Nordstrom family “is leaning towards a partnership” with private-equity firm Leonard Green, which would provide roughly $1bn in equity to help fund the deal.Nordstrom announced in June that members of its founding family had formed a group to study the possibility of taking the Seattle-based business private after more than 39 years as a public company, as they look to navigate the industry-wide slowdown in retail.

Titular: Nordstrom shares drop after it announces inventory-less store
Texto: Wall Street isn’t lining up for Nordstrom’s latest retail foray — a store without inventory.The company’s shares fell more than 4 per cent on Monday after the US department store chain announced plans to launch its first “Nordstrom Local” store in West Hollywood next month.The move comes as retailers — and especially department stores, a traditional anchor of shopping malls — look to retrench to counteract declining customer foot traffic and online competition. Some companies, like Sears and Target, are exploring smaller-format stores to try to lure back shoppers.Nordstrom said on Monday that its Nordstrom Local will have a 3,000 square-foot footprint, compared to its average 140,000-square foot full store. Instead of dedicated inventory, the store will have just one “styling suite” and eight dressing rooms, where shoppers are meant to interact with “personal stylists” who can bring merchandise in for them to peruse. The store will also complement Nordstrom’s online offerings, serving as a hub for customers to pick up their digital purchases or have them altered or tailored.Shea Johnson, Nordstrom’s senior vice-president of customer experience, said in a statement:As the retail landscape continues to transform at an unprecedented pace, the one thing we know that remains constant is that customers continue to value great service, speed and convenience. We know there are more and more demands on a customer’s time and we wanted to offer our best services in a convenient location to meet their shopping needs.In recent quarters, Nordstrom has been seen as better positioned to weather broad retail challenges than department-store rivals like Macy’s, thanks in part to growing online sales and growth for its Nordstrom Rack discount-focused stores.Nevertheless, the sector’s headwinds prompted members of the founding Nordstrom family to form a group to explore the possibility of taking the company private.Year-to-date, Nordstrom shares are down almost 8 per cent, according to Thomson Reuters data. By midday trading, it was on track for its worst one-day fall since last month at 4.3 per cent.

Titular: US department stores: on the rack
Subtitular: Sector has been brutalised by the shift towards e-commerce
Texto: Some industries have cartels to protect their collective interests. US department stores fight between themselves instead.The sector has been brutalised by the shift towards e-commerce. Sector earnings this week revealed a modest stabilisation at stalwarts, Macy’s, Nordstrom, and Kohl’s that proved all-too fragile.On Friday, JC Penney said that heavy discounting had pushed it into a wider loss than expected. Shares in the company crashed by nearly a fifth.As department stores execute a painful retreat, the price wars they engage in to maintain market share resemble passengers on a sinking ship fighting over life vests.Macy’s said this week that it was comfortable with its full-year forecast of like-for-like sales down by 2-3 per cent.On this basis, earnings per share would fall by as much as nearly a tenth. It is furiously shutting down or monetising unproductive stores.But even after presenting a set of reassuring results, its shares have lost more than 10 per cent in the past week and have almost halved in the past year. This is the same sort of treatment meted out to Penney’s, whose prospects are far more dim.Each store faces pressure to keep fighting. In retail, that means cutting prices. Macy’s boss Jeff Gennette said: “We expect the fourth quarter to be very promotional. And it is — and we’re going to have all of our firepower ready to go for that.”Sears and JC Penney are cutting prices to keep their heads above water. Macy’s and other ostensible survivors have to cut prices, too.Hudson’s Bay, the owner of the Saks and Lord & Taylor chains, has an activist advising it to abandon retail and sell its flagship property. The Dillards chain is getting similar advice.The natural reaction would be for groups to combine. But complicated liabilities and integration constrain that. Expect stock prices to keep falling as fast as prices on the clothes racks.Do you want to receive Lex in your inbox? Sign up for the weekly Best of Lex email at www.ft.com/newsletters.

Titular: Nordstrom bucks the department-store slump with upbeat earnings
Texto: A better-than-expected showing at its annual “anniversary sale”, growing online sales and improving merchandise margins have helped Nordstrom beat the broader department-store slump and post stronger profits and sales growth than analysts had expected.On Thursday, Nordstrom said that second-quarter net sales rose 3.5 per cent year-over-year to $3.71bn, just a hair shy of the $3.75bn that analysts surveyed by Bloomberg had expected. Comparable sales, a key industry metric, rose 1.7 per cent during the quarter, beating forecasts for an 0.4 per cent decline.Of that, comparable sales at Nordstrom-brand stores and online grew 1.4 per cent — led by women’s apparel and beauty divisions — while comparable sales at its discount-driven Nordstrom Rack increased 3.1 per cent.Net earnings came in at $110m, beating predictions for $108.2m, and earnings per diluted share were 65 cents, better than the 63.5 cents that Wall Street was looking for.The company credited its sales growth with an anniversary sale that “performed better than recent trends” as well “improved merchandise margins, reflecting the continued strength in regular price selling.” Online sales growth from Nordstrom.com also reached 20 per cent during the quarter, the company said.The solid second quarter performance prompted Nordstrom to boost the bottom end of its full-year forecasts. It is now looking for net sales to grow about 4 per cent, compared to a previous range of 3-4 per cent and earnings per diluted share of $2.85 to $3.00, versus previous forecasts for $2.75-$3.00.The results come after a grim day of earnings for fellow big US department-store chains Macy’s, Kohl’s and Dillard’s. While sales declines at the three retailers were not as steep as feared, news of falling profit margins was enough to trigger a fresh sell-off.The declining fortunes of department stores have recently prompted members of the founding Nordstrom family to form a group to study the possibility of taking the Seattle-based business private after more than 39 years as a public company.Nordstrom shares, which are down 6.7 per cent year to date, rose 1.8 per cent in after-hours trading after falling 4.3 per cent during the trading session.

Titular: Dealmakers flock to a retail industry in flux
Subtitular: Welcome to Due Diligence, the FT’s daily deals briefing
Texto: The bloodbath among US department stores has quickly grabbed the attention of Wall Street dealmakers.On Thursday, Seattle-based Nordstrom said it would examine a go-private deal led by the Nordstrom family. The family owns about a third of the company (and three Nordstroms are co-presidents in lieu of a single chief executive).A deal would likely be valued at about $10bn. But, as Lex noted on Thursday, the family could buy out public shareholders without relying on a private equity infusion.This would require nearly $6bn of new debt. But overall leverage would still be below 5x ebitda, so an aggressive bank could make that number work. Centerview and Sidley Austin are working with the independent directors who will negotiate with the Nordstrom family, who are being represented by Moelis, on a deal.Financial engineers are hard at work across the department store industry. Neiman Marcus has been reported to be the target of Hudson’s Bay — which just announced 2,000 job cuts — the owner of Saks. But Neiman needs a debt restructuring, which apparently has slowed the merger talks.Meanwhile, industry stalwart Macy’s has some interesting choices to make. Its shares are down 70 per cent in the past two years. But with much of its real estate owned, it has a series of options on how to monetise its property. And no shortage of private equity and hedge funds are willing to help it figure out what to do.Retail M&A has reached its highest level since 2007, according to a May Dealogic report. That’s no surprise — there are few things dealmakers like more than an industry in flux.Welcome to the FT’s curated briefing on deals and dealmaking. Due Diligence is your gateway to the best M&A stories, insights, analysis and exclusives. Each day we expand on three topics, followed by a section of smart reads from the FT and elsewhere. Lower down you’ll find job moves and a round-up of key headlines. Get DD delivered to your inbox Tuesday-Friday at 5am UK time and see all previous editions by clicking here. Want to get in touch? Due.Diligence@FT.comDonald Trump is bad for deals. Dealogic data show that so far this year M&A activity in the US is down 11 per cent compared with a year ago as a barrage of scandals inside the White House sparks uncertainty over the prospect of tax reform, forcing chief executives to put deals on ice. John Purcell, a veteran banker at JPMorgan Chase, said that Trump has had a “chilling effect on deal activity”. Speaking at a conference held by S&P Global Ratings in New York, he added: “Personally, I’ve had three M&A deals die since Trump was elected.”The opposite is true in Europe (as the chart above shows), where overall M&A activity is up more than 25 per cent so far compared with the same period last year. Some bankers told DD that the recent victory of Emmanuel Macron in France’s presidential election, as well as the defeat of far-right parties in the Dutch polls, had helped lift European business confidence.The deal bonanza in Europe was driven by a jump in activity in France and Italy. The chart below shows the bump nicely (particularly in Italy). Dealmakers insist that the appetite for deals in the US remains robust. The problem, they say, is the uncertainty and confusion created by the administration. If Trump manages to clear the clouds over his administration, we might just witness a boom in deals. But that’s a big if (see James Comey’s gripping testimony on Thursday). They say there’s no such thing as bad assets, just bad prices. It’s a motto toxic debt investors in China must be taking to heart as they take on some of the trickiest deals in the region. Global investors might be catching on to that idea too. ShoreVest, a distressed debt investor based in southern China, told the Financial Times that it is raising a $750m fund for buying bad debt portfolios in China, drawing in interest from sovereign wealth and pension funds. Over the past few months, major investors such as Bain Capital, Lone Star and Hong Kong’s PAG have also moved into the market.Bad debt deals in China are not for the faint of heart. Even experienced distressed-debt hands have steered clear of the market in recent years.China is in the throes of a bad debt epidemic — up to $3tn in the market now — and many of those assets will never be recoverable. The courts in China can make things more difficult. Many companies desperately need restructuring or liquidation but local courts often choose to keep zombie groups alive if it keeps people working.That leaves bad debt dealmakers with a surplus of risky opportunities. Only after years of experience do investors figure out where they can ultimately squeeze returns out of the unsavoury debt loads. The secret is pricing in hidden risks such as government interference in deals, and often paying pennies on the dollar for the murkiest loans.ShoreVest’s fundraising and the new entrants into the China distressed market indicate that investors are becoming more confident with dealmakers’ ability to pull it off.Paul Singer’s hedge fund Elliott has recruited Paul Best, a Warburg Pincus managing director, as it looks to expand into European private equity, the WSJ reports. It added that Best started this week in London and will report to Singer’s son Gordon, who runs the Europe office.Deutsche Bank has hired Nick Richitt as a managing director in its healthcare investment banking team. Richitt, who joins from SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, will focus on healthcare IT and outsourcing.Matthew Zames, the chief operating officer at JPMorgan who was seen as a potential successor to chief executive Jamie Dimon, is leaving the bank, the FT reported.Andrew Hede and Adam Chepenik are joining the US restructuring advisory practice at EY. Hede joins from Alvarez & Marsal and will be based in New York, while Chepenik, who will be based in Washington, joins from the US Treasury department, where he was deputy director of the office of state and local finance.How Banco became momentarily Popular Our reporters give you the inside story of how Banco Popular ended up in the hands of Santander. (FT)Junk bond investors win rare victory over covenants High-yield investors successfully pushed Superior Industries to strip out a controversial clause in a debt sale on Thursday, marking a rare victory for bond buyers in their tussle with sellers over aggressive deal terms. (FT)Small is lucrative for Wachtell Meet Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, the most lucrative legal outfit in the world and the go-to shop for deal-hungry companies — and those looking to stave off an activist investor. Titular: Nordstrom: Ivanka be alone
Subtitular: Possibility that department store will go private signals bottom of retail market
Texto: The three members of the Nordstrom family who collectively run the eponymous US luxury department chain are driven by economics rather than sentiment.A shareholder recently asked why the retailer dropped Ivanka Trump’s clothing line. Co-president Peter Nordstrom calmly explained that the first daughter’s assortment “performed very, very poorly for us in the last year”.The Nordstroms are more bullish on their business’ broader prospects. The family, which owns a third of the Seattle-based company, is considering buying out the listed group. For the battered department store sector, the move signals the bottom of the market.Assuming a 25 per cent premium to Nordstrom’s closing price on Wednesday, the enterprise value would be $10.5bn. This values the company at a modest six times earnings, before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation.Nordstrom would then need to come up with just under $6bn in debt to buy out public shareholders. With $2bn of borrowings outstanding, the ratio of debt to earnings before such deductions as interest and tax would rise to just under five times.Raising only debt finance at that level, without private equity, would be a huge vote of confidence in the Nordstrom business. The family has not mentioned any buyout group waiting in the wings to finance the bid.The shares have fallen 50 per cent since peaking in 2015. But it has been a leader in adapting to the trends in retail.A quarter of its sales are online and it has acquired upstart e-commerce concepts like Trunk Club and HauteLook. Nearly a third of sales come from its discount format, Rack. Still, the diminution of its core, high-touch department store experience is real. Nordstrom’s operating margin has halved in the past four years.Recalling the ruthlessness with which Nordstrom ditched Ivanka, independent shareholders should fear the same fate. The family knows the company’s prospects best and its offer looks opportunistic. The price should not be opportunistically cheap, too.Email the Lex team at lex@ft.com

Titular: Nordstrom family considers taking department store private
Subtitular: Group to study options as industry faces sales slowdown
Texto: After more than 39 years as a public company, Nordstrom, the venerable US department store chain that started life as a single shoe shop more than 110 years ago, could well become private again.The upmarket retailer said on Thursday that members of the founding Nordstrom family have formed a group to study the possibility of taking the Seattle-based business private as they look to navigate the industry-wide slowdown in sales.The group — whose members collectively hold more than a third of Nordstrom stocks, according to Bloomberg data — has not made any formal proposals yet.Any deal would require the family to acquire 100 per cent of Nordstrom’s outstanding shares, however, and Nordstrom cautioned that there was no guarantee that an offer would be made or accepted by the company.Still, the prospect of a buyout sent shares in Nordstrom up by as much as 18 per cent, to give the company a market value of nearly $8bn.Before Thursday, the stock had shed more than 15 per cent of its value since the start of the year as it struggled to weather the malaise that has engulfed the wider US retail sector.Retailers are facing unprecedented upheaval amid falling mall traffic,
